subject: Re: [junit] Before/After
msgSnippet: While you are reviewing, one point I ve heard others make about JUnit is that the ignore annotation is very much geared to giving the runner an instruction,
messageBody:
While you are reviewing, one point I've heard others make about JUnit
is that the ignore annotation is very much geared to giving the runner
an instruction, not how the developer is expected to use it.

When using outside-in testingstyle it's quite common to "recurse" down
until you are at a point when you can actually implement something.
When you have arrived to that point you have a trail of "pending"
tests that you activate one by one as you implement your way back to
the outer starting point. In that scenario, "pending" would be more in
line with how the developer uses JUnit.

I'll try to illustrate:

winning hand is printed first : pending - We need to find the kicker
when two hands are the same
highest card wins of two complete hands: failed
complete hand is detected: pass
fold is detected: pass

The above was not testdriven, in reality the tests might be different
but I hope it illustrates my point, the first test written is at the
top. I view it as a "stack" and we have started to "roll back" by
making the two bottommost tests pass and just removed @pending("we
need to be able to detect complete hand") from the "second" test.

Another related extremely cool feature would be if like with rspec, an
empty test-body would automatically become pending (have no idea how I
would solve that... A test that does not make any asserts?).

Perhaps also a pending-block:
new Pending("I need to implement the other stuff before something
useful is done here") {{
assertThat(something, is("something useful"));
}};
Would go from "pending" to "fixed" when the assertion passes which
signals that you can remove the pending-block.

I understand that this is mostly "sugar" and that the verdict may be
that it would violate JUnit's "intersection" philosophy but I thought
there would be no harm in expressing my whishes, right?

Best regards,
Joakim Ohlrogge
